Now we will explain why Yosef needed both proofs together, since each proof was a complete verification as mentioned above. If so, one should have been sufficient. One can explain that although it was verified to them through seeing the milah (circumcision) that he was a complete tzaddik (righteous person), as they saw upon him the Divine Presence (hashra'at Shemo Yitbarach) as mentioned above, and it was impossible to mistake him for an Arab who was circumcised or from the children of Keturah.

Perhaps he was only changing his speech to ease their minds and for the sake of Heaven (l'shem shamayim) by saying he was Yosef, because he saw their spiritual distress. Also, since the tribes were prepared for war to kill him and the entire city as stated in the Midrash, they were concerned that perhaps he changed his speech in the way our Sages said it is permitted to change [the truth] for the sake of peace (mipnei darchei shalom), and perhaps he would later reveal to them that he wasn't their brother Yosef.

However, their doubts were resolved through seeing his language capability, for regarding the aspect of language that was at the level of "seeing what is heard," which is impossible except through the Divine Presence (hashra'at HaShechinah) speaking through his throat. From this they knew that his mouth and heart were aligned and he wasn't changing his speech, for the Divine Presence cannot rest upon false speech, Heaven forbid. If the words weren't truthful, even in a permitted way such as changing for the sake of peace or because of danger, it would have been impossible for the Shechinah to speak through his throat. Therefore, from this they knew with clear proof that truth was in his mouth and that he was indeed their brother Yosef.

However, the explanation of the matter is that if Hashem's intention was only to rectify their encampment places, the journey from place to place could have been accomplished through kefitzat haderech (miraculous shortening of the way) or through the clouds. The Holy One, Blessed be He, would not have troubled them with the journey through the great and awesome desert, for in any case, the journey was miraculous and assisted by the clouds, as our Sages said. If so, the entire journey could have been through the clouds.

But the will and necessity was to rectify and elevate the holy sparks (nitzotzot hakdoshim) along their entire journey route, and the journey itself was an important divine service in its own right. Therefore, it was necessary for their journey to be by foot through the desert path, for if it had been through kefitzat haderech and skipping, they would not have passed through all these places, and the holy sparks there would not have been rectified and elevated.

Therefore, the verse states "they journeyed and encamped" at each journey, and it wasn't sufficient to mention only the encampments, because the journey itself was also a divine service and purpose of rectification just like the encampments. From this, we can explain as Ibn Ezra wrote that when it says "Moses wrote their goings forth according to their journeys by the command of Hashem," it teaches that their journeys were by Hashem's command. This resolves Ramban's question about the redundancy with the earlier verse "by Hashem's command they would camp and by Hashem's command they would journey."

For one might still think that the main purpose was the encampments, and after their encampment place was rectified and they needed another encampment, their journey was by Hashem's command, but the journey was secondary and merely a means to the purpose of the encampments. Therefore, the verse repeats to say "according to their journeys by the command of Hashem," without mentioning the encampments in this verse, to teach that the journeys themselves were an important divine service and by Hashem's command.

It is worthy to understand that while what he said about "if for war" and "if for appeasement" makes sense, as he made it conditional and uncertain - that if war is desired, he would fight with him, and if appeasement is desired, he would enter into appeasement with him - but regarding what he said "if for prayer," how could he make prayer conditional and uncertain? Indeed, their holy words remain eternal for all generations, as they paved the way and opened a wellspring of salvation for their children after them. As the holy Yitav Lev wrote (in Parshat Toldot) regarding what is found in the holy Zohar: "Isaac waited twenty years with his wife who did not bear children until he prayed his prayer, because the Holy One, blessed be He, desires the prayers of tzaddikim (righteous ones). Why? Because through the prayers of tzaddikim, holy abundance increases and is added for all who need it."

The holy Yitav Lev wrote that this is comparable to a blocked pipe - if someone comes and opens it and cleans it out, it then remains open for all. Similarly, through the prayers of tzaddikim, the channels of salvation and kindness are opened, and whoever needs the waters of salvation can draw joyfully from that pipe, as it is written, "And you shall draw water with joy from the wellsprings of salvation." The commentators explained that the salvation of tzaddikim is like a flowing spring bringing salvation immediately and for generations, and therefore the Holy One, blessed be He, desires their prayers, for through their prayers the pipe and spring are opened for all who need that thing.

This explains the words of the Midrash: "Deep waters are counsel in the heart of man..." - A parable of a deep well full of cold water, and its waters were cold and good, but no creature could drink from it. Someone came and tied rope to rope, etc., and drew from it and drank. Then everyone began drawing and drinking from it. Similarly, Judah did not cease responding to Joseph, etc.

The holy tribes did not need these actions for themselves, as they had the power of their holiness to bring about salvation for themselves regardless. But they did all this so that there would be a wellspring of salvation flowing for generations, and there is relevance in their holy words for all generations, each generation according to its situation and circumstances. Therefore their words showed different aspects, so that the flowing spring of salvation would continue for generations for whoever needs it. The words of the Midrash mentioned above (in the previous drush) can be explained: "And Judah approached him" - Rabbi Yehuda says it was an approach for war, Rabbi Nechemia says it was an approach for appeasement, etc., and the Rabbis say it was an approach for prayer - and all these are the words of the living G-d. All these aspects were included in his words.

As we explained regarding Joseph's words, besides their simple meaning, the inner meaning of the words contained hints to lofty and hidden matters. Similarly were Judah's words, as written in the holy sefer Noam Elimelech (in Parshat Vayishlach) on the verse "Thus shall you say to my master, to Esau: 'I have sojourned with Laban, etc.'"

He [the Noam Elimelech] questioned why Jacob needed to mention and call Esau "my master" when speaking to the angels in his house. Also, the letter "lamed" in "l'Esau" (to Esau) seems unnecessary - he should have said "adoni Esau" (my master Esau). Furthermore, regarding Rashi's explanation that "I have sojourned with Laban" means "I kept the 613 mitzvot," would this really find favor in Esau's eyes?

Rather, the matter is that when a tzaddik speaks with people, he is precise in his words, ensuring that his words are heard in their simple meaning by the person he's speaking with, while the main content he intends with those words is prayer and supplication before HaKadosh Baruch Hu. The intention is to hide his words of prayer within the conversation he has with the person, and he doesn't explicitly state his needed prayer in order that the prosecutor (satan) won't understand his intention and won't prosecute him.

This is what Jacob said to the angels: "Thus shall you say" - in this manner and with this intention you should say all your words - "to my master," meaning your intention should be to the Master of All, the Blessed Creator, while also having a simple meaning for Esau that would be pleasing to him. This is why it says "Thus says your servant Jacob: 'I have sojourned with Laban,'" which can be understood in two ways: as words of advocacy before Hashem that he kept the 613 mitzvot, and this merit should protect him from Esau, and also in its simple meaning as words of appeasement and submission to Esau, that he was merely a stranger and didn't become important or powerful, as Rashi explains.

Similarly can be explained Judah's words to Joseph when he said "Please, my master, let your servant speak a word in my master's ears." When he mentioned "my master," the inner content of his words was prayer and supplication before the Creator, speaking words toward Above, but he concealed and clothed in his words also the simple meaning that would be words of appeasement and harsh words to Joseph. This explains well what our Sages said in the Midrash that this approach was for appeasement and for war with Joseph according to the simple meaning, and an approach of prayer to the Creator as mentioned above.

One can explain by first considering what our Sages taught (Berachos 5a): A person should always incite the yetzer tov (good inclination) against the yetzer hara (evil inclination), as it is said "Tremble and sin not." If he overcomes it, good; if not, he should engage in Torah study, as it is said "Speak in your hearts, etc." If this doesn't help, he should recite Krias Shema, etc. If this doesn't help, he should remember the day of death.

The Iyun Yaakov (by the author of Shvus Yaakov) asks why go through all this - why not immediately suggest remembering the day of death, since its effectiveness is clear and certain? He answers that sadness is not good, as it is written "And I praise joy" - referring to the joy of mitzvos, and the Shechinah (Divine Presence) only rests in a state of joy, as we learn in Berachos 31b and other places. Therefore, it first suggests engaging in Torah or reciting Krias Shema, and only if these don't help should one remember the day of death.

The commentators explain allegorically the verse "Behold now, I have grown old, I know not the day of my death" - Yitzchak Avinu said that despite his advanced age, he never needed to know or remember his day of death, because he knew how to overcome the yetzer hara through the power of Torah and Krias Shema, serving Hashem with joy. However, Yaakov Avinu, as long as he was in distress mourning for Yosef and the Shechinah departed from him (as our Sages say), couldn't overcome the yetzer hara through Torah and Krias Shema and through the joy of mitzvos, and needed to overcome it by remembering the day of death. This is hinted at in the verse "For I will go down to my son mourning to Sheol" - meaning that through the pain of mourning for Yosef, when the Shechinah departed from him, he was forced to descend from his level of overcoming the yetzer hara through Krias Shema or Torah and the joy of mitzvos, and only the remedy of Sheol remained - overcoming it through remembering the day of death.

We can explain the verse "to establish for you a remnant in the land, etc." based on what is said in the Gemara regarding ribis (interest) [Bava Metzia 75b]: Those who transgress the negative commandment are the lender, borrower, guarantor, and witnesses. Abaye said the lender transgresses all [prohibitions], etc., while the guarantor and witnesses only transgress "you shall not place upon him interest."

The Gemara [62a] asks: While all others perform an action, what action do the witnesses perform? Rather, is it not that the very act of establishing [the loan] is significant? Thus, even though the guarantor and witnesses didn't perform an actual deed in the matter itself, because the transaction was completed through them, they are liable for the prohibition of "you shall not place," with the root of the action being included in the word "placing."

Similarly, in our matter, Yosef HaTzaddik preceded going to Egypt to prepare a place for Bnei Yisrael so they could maintain their kedushah (holiness) in Egyptian exile, which was the ervat ha'aretz (most defiled land) and extremely contaminated. Through the power of his kedushah and the trials he withstood and overcame, and by becoming ruler over the sar (angel) of Egypt, he weakened the power of tumah (impurity) and klipot (negative forces) at their root.

Through this, Israel merited to be protected from immorality in Egypt - "Bnei Yisrael entered and Bnei Yisrael left" - and not one of them was born from improper relations, as our Sages said. Moreover, Yosef HaTzaddik prepared a power of salvation for future generations until the final exile, so that Israel could overcome and withstand the trials of exile and maintain their kedushah even in the terrible lowliness of ikveta d'meshicha (the footsteps of Mashiach), as the Egyptian exile is the root of all exiles.

The holy Avot and Shevatim were the root of all Jewish souls throughout the generations, and whatever exists in the branch exists in the root. Therefore, through their holy actions, they opened a channel and prepared strength for all generations of Israel. This is the meaning of "to establish for you a remnant in the land and to sustain you for a great deliverance" - that Yosef HaTzaddik established a foundation and root of strength for all generations of Israel. This is the holy spark which is hidden within the nefesh (soul) of every Jew, inherited from our holy forefathers. At first, it is only at the level of a "remnant," but afterward, the boundary of kedushah expands "to sustain you for a great deliverance."

One can suggest another praiseworthy reason why someone whose intention and thoughts are proper is permitted to make a vow even if they don't have the means to give immediately. For one whose mind is properly focused participates in the pain of the needy person. Consequently, their heart won't feel bad about giving; on the contrary, their heart will ache more for the trouble of their fellow who needs to receive their donation. And since they share in the pain of the recipient, it is considered a time of distress, and the Tur and Shulchan Aruch ruled in Hilchos Nedarim (203:7) that during a time of distress it is permitted to make vows, even with "Harei Alu."

Perhaps in such a case there is no concern that it might lead to a stumbling block, as they will certainly fulfill their vow. This is what the verse means when it states, "Your heart shall not be grieved when you give to him." Rather, if your intention is proper, then "because of this matter, Hashem your G-d will bless you" - that you will receive reward even for the speech itself.

From this, there is support for the common practice at gatherings for supporting Torah institutions and yeshivos, where people announce and promise sums of money for tzedakah, even though not everyone has the means to pay immediately and say "Harei Zu." Nevertheless, with proper intention, the speech itself becomes a separate mitzvah, and one receives reward both for the declaration and the action.

However, each person should take to heart that they have a great responsibility to fulfill their vow, as this is our entire existence. We have no portion or inheritance in financial support that comes from impure sources, which are mainly given to unstable and corrupted institutions. I don't want to touch them as they are dangerous, Heaven forbid, to the spiritual nature of those who receive them.

The main foundation for maintaining our institutions comes only from those who fear Hashem, who are few.
